rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;7e861a60.1503">   <title>AEA conference Foodscapes Registration deadline this Friday </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;7e861a60.1503</link>   <description> Dear all,<br>This is a final reminder that registration for the upcoming AEA conference at Nottingham on the 28th of March with the theme 'Crossing Boundaries: the Creation of Foodscapes' is open only until tomorrow (13th of March). More information and a preview of the programme can be found here:<br><br>http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/archaeology/research/conferences/foodscapes/foodscapes.aspx<br><br>For the registration please follow the link: [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T17:38:05+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alexandra Livarda</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;7e861a60.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;fedf62fd.1503">   <title>Post-excavation posts at NAA in County Durham </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;fedf62fd.1503</link>   <description> Dear all, (apologies for cross-posting)<br>We are looking to expand our existing palaeoenvironmental and finds teams and are recruiting for the following new posts to assist with the processing of material recovered during the ongoing excavations on the A1 Leeming to Barton Improvements, North Yorkshire. The main assemblages relate to excavations investigating Catterick Roman fort and town, associated Roman cemetery and the early Roman settlement at Scotch Corner. The fort and associated town are scheduled as being of national importance and this is an exciting opportunity to work with a very rich and significant assemblage of material of a scale [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T11:39:43+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Hannah Russ</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;fedf62fd.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;4b1054d7.1503">   <title>NEW open access article in STAR: Calculating a statistically robust \ufffd\ufffd13C and \ufffd\ufffd15N offset for charred cereal and pulse seeds</title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;4b1054d7.1503</link>   <description> NEW open access article in STAR: Science and Technology of Archaeological Research<br><br>Calculating a statistically robust \ufffd\ufffd13C and \ufffd\ufffd15N offset for charred cereal and pulse seeds<br><br>http://www.maneyonline.com/doi/abs/10.1179/2054892315Y.0000000001<br><br>Authors: Dr Erika Nitsch, Dr Michael Charles and Dr Amy Bogaard, Institute of Archaeology, University of Oxford, UK<br><br>This study measured \ufffd\ufffd13C and \ufffd\ufffd15N of fresh and charred seeds from six different taxa of cereals and pulses. For each taxon, 12 different batches of seeds, all from the same growing context or field, were charred for 4, 8, or 24?hours at 215, 230, 245, or 260\ufffd\ufffdC, with the thirteenth batch left uncharred. The [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T09:08:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Jennifer Collinson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;4b1054d7.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5e5e43f8.1503">   <title>AEA seminar-Cork (25th March) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5e5e43f8.1503</link>   <description> Dear All,<br><br>The next AEA seminar is in Cork in 3 weeks' time:<br><br>25th March 18.30<br>Professor Kevin Edwards (University of Aberdeen)<br>'People, pollen and the past: the Norse in the North Atlantic'<br>Boole 1, School of Geography and Archaeology, University College Cork, Ireland<br><br>Refreshments will be served. All welcome<br><br>Best regards<br><br>Richard<br><br>Dr Richard Madgwick<br>British Academy Post-Doctoral Research Fellow<br>School of History, Archaeology and Religion<br>Cardiff University<br>Colum Drive<br>Cardiff<br>CF10 3EU [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T13:52:11+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Richard Madgwick</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5e5e43f8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;27ece3a4.1503">   <title>looking for AEA member Kate Clark </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;27ece3a4.1503</link>   <description> Does anyone have contact information for Kate Clark (zooarchaeologist) please?<br><br>Best wishes<br><br>Ruth<br><br>Dr Ruth Pelling<br>Senior Archaeobotanist<br>English Heritage<br>Fort Cumberland<br>Fort Cumberland Road<br>Eastney<br>Portsmouth<br>Hampshire<br>PO4 9LD<br>Tel: 02392 856776<br><br>Office Days: Monday, Tuesday andThursday<br><br>Ruth.Pelling@english-heritage.org.uk&lt;mailto:Ruth.Pelling@english-heritage.org.uk&gt;<br>Membership Secretary, Association for Environmental Archaeology http://www.envarch.net/<br><br>English Heritage is changing into two organisations.<br><br>From Spring 2015, we shall become Historic England, a government service championing England's heritage and giving expert, constructive advice, and the English Heritage Trust, a charity caring for the National Heritage Collection of more than 400 historic properties and their collections. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T14:07:40+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Pelling, Ruth</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;27ece3a4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8d85022d.1503">   <title>Re: query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8d85022d.1503</link>   <description> The Neolithic trackway excavated by Chapman and Gearey on Hatfield Moors, S<br>Yorks, was left in situ and eventually surrounded by a coffer dam.<br>Unfortunately by this time the corduroy of even-aged pines had largely<br>dried out and flooding resulted in several of the<br>timbers floating off. Nothing remains to be seen.<br><br>On 02 March 2015 at 11:16 &quot;Straker, Vanessa&quot;<br>&lt;Vanessa.Straker@ENGLISH-HERITAGE.ORG.UK&gt; wrote: [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T11:57:51+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Paul Buckland</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8d85022d.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;488399cb.1503">   <title>Re: query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;488399cb.1503</link>   <description> Apologies \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd nothing in situ in Somerset.<br><br>Vanessa<br><br>From: Straker, Vanessa<br>Sent: 02 March 2015 09:57<br>To: ENV-ARCH@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: RE: query about Flag Fen<br><br>Somerset County Museum in Taunton used to display some pieces of conserved wooden trackways and the Tribunal Museum in Glastonbury has some of the artefacts from Glastonbury Lake Village plus a log boat. The curator of archaeology is Steve Minnitt (Steve.Minnitt@swheritage.org.uk&lt;mailto:Steve.Minnitt@swheritage.org.uk&gt;) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the County Museum has reopened with new displays and I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm not sure whether the waterlogged wood is still on display. Poole Museum has an excellent log boat on display. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T11:16:02+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Straker, Vanessa</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;488399cb.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8eaa822.1503">   <title>Re: query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8eaa822.1503</link>   <description> Hi again, Andy<br><br>I forgot to say, the Oakbank Crannog piles and artefacts on display at the<br>Crannog Centre on Loch Tayside are on the opposite bank of the loch, where<br>visitor access is better, so technically not in situ as such, but within<br>plain view of the actual recovery site.<br><br>Jen<br><br>On 2 March 2015 at 09:12, Andy Howard &lt;<br>andy.howard@landscape-research-management.co.uk&gt; wrote: [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T10:33:48+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Jennifer Miller</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8eaa822.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8e920baa.1503">   <title>Re: query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8e920baa.1503</link>   <description> Somerset County Museum in Taunton used to display some pieces of conserved wooden trackways and the Tribunal Museum in Glastonbury has some of the artefacts from Glastonbury Lake Village plus a log boat. The curator of archaeology is Steve Minnitt (Steve.Minnitt@swheritage.org.uk&lt;mailto:Steve.Minnitt@swheritage.org.uk&gt;) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the County Museum has reopened with new displays and I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm not sure whether the waterlogged wood is still on display. Poole Museum has an excellent log boat on display. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T09:57:13+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Straker, Vanessa</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;8e920baa.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5eae2a89.1503">   <title>Re: query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5eae2a89.1503</link>   <description> Dear Andy,<br><br>Off the top of my head the only other case I can think of may be the Somerset Levels Visitor centre but I am not sure of its present status.<br><br>What\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds is being published since I have three sites from the basin with good insect faunas so a companion piece may be warranted. Of course as this is not international it would only be a REF 2* but there you go. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T09:32:58+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>David Smith</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;5eae2a89.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;b4c1a86a.1503">   <title>query about Flag Fen </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;b4c1a86a.1503</link>   <description> Hi,<br><br>I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm just reviewing a piece of text at the moment that states<br><br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFlag Fen is the only location in the UK where wetland archaeological remains are on permanent display in situ\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<br><br>is this statement true? All thoughts gratefully received before this gets set in stone (print).<br><br>BW<br><br>A<br><br>co-writing a piece of tex<br>Dr Andy Howard MCIfA<br>Landscape Research &amp; Management<br>Tel. +44 (0)1746 769739<br>Mob. 07791 840205<br>Skype: andy.howard14<br>http://landscape-research-management.co.uk/ [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T09:12:48-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Andy Howard</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;b4c1a86a.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d13ab1ca.1503">   <title>AEA March conference Foodscapes </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d13ab1ca.1503</link>   <description> *Apologies for cross-posting*<br><br>Dear all,<br>Just a reminder that registration is open (deadline 13th of March) for the upcoming AEA conference at Nottingham on the 28th of March with the theme 'Crossing Boundaries: the Creation of Foodscapes'. For more information and a preview of the programme of what promises to be an exciting and international day, can be found here: [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T20:25:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alexandra Livarda</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d13ab1ca.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;630d2c54.1502">   <title>NEW open access article published in STAR: Modern humans' paleogenomics and the new evidences on the European prehistory </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;630d2c54.1502</link>   <description> New open access article published in STAR: Science and Technology of Archaeological Research<br><br>'Modern humans' paleogenomics and the new evidences on the European prehistory'<br><br>By I\ufffd\ufffdigo Olalde and Carles Lalueza-Fox<br><br>Read the article: http://www.maneyonline.com/doi/abs/10.1179/2054892315Y.0000000002<br><br>The modern human settlement of Europe is a complex process with overimposed migrations and regionalisation episodes, as well as adaptive processes that shaped the genome of modern populations. New developments in massive sequencing techniques allow now the generation of an unprecedented amount of genomic data, including the genotyping of a large number of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and the generation of complete ancient genomes. These paleogenomic [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-26T09:57:36+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Jennifer Collinson</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;630d2c54.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;525d7203.1502">   <title>AEA seminar-2nd March, Oxford </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;525d7203.1502</link>   <description> Dear All,<br><br>A quick reminder about next week's AEA seminar:<br><br>2nd March 17.00<br><br>Professor Soultana Valamoti (Aristotle University of Thessaloniki): 'A sip of Neolithic wine: recent finds from the north Aegean'<br><br>Institute of Archaeology Lecture Room, 36 Beaumont Street, University of Oxford, Oxford, OX1 2PG<br><br>Refreshments will be served. All welcome<br><br>Best regards<br><br>Richard<br><br>Dr Richard Madgwick<br>British Academy Post-Doctoral Research Fellow<br>School of History, Archaeology and Religion<br>Cardiff University<br>Colum Drive<br>Cardiff<br>CF10 3EU [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T14:50:38+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Richard Madgwick</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;525d7203.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f72165c4.1502">   <title>Integrating Environmental and Theoretical Roman Archaeology TRAC session - registration deadline 27th Feb </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f72165c4.1502</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>A quick reminder that the final date for registering for the Theoretical Roman Archaeology Conference (featuring an AEA supported session) is this Friday.<br><br>Best wishes,<br><br>Lisa Lodwick<br>AEA session at TRAC 2015<br><br>The AEA are supporting a session taking place on the Sunday of the Theoretical Roman Archaeology Conference this year (Sunday 29th March), on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIntegrating Environmental and Theoretical Roman Archaeology\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.<br>TRAC 2015 is taking place at the University of Leicester, and the full programme is available here http://trac.org.uk/conferences/trac2015/programme/. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-24T11:24:56+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Lisa Lodwick</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f72165c4.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;e941fc7.1502">   <title>PhD funding opportunities </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;e941fc7.1502</link>   <description> There are two competitive, fully funded (UK/EU) studentships available at the Department of Geography &amp; Sustainable Development, University of St Andrews. The deadline for expressions of interest is Friday 27th Feb: http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/gsd/opportunities/pg/phdfunding/<br><br>We have a recently expanded Environmental Change group, with interests in environmental archaeology and palaeoecology in the UK, Iceland, Mediterranean and tropics. A list of indicative projects can be found here and we welcome enquiries related to these or other areas in this field of research: http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/gsd/opportunities/pg/physgeo/ [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-19T15:53:24+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Althea Davies</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;e941fc7.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a5c3d7a6.1502">   <title>Workshop on Agent-Based Models in Ecology, June 15-19, Spain </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a5c3d7a6.1502</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br><br>Registration is open for the course &quot;INTRODUCTION TO INDIVIDUAL BASED<br>MODELS IN ECOLOGY USING NETLOGO&quot;, June 15-19, 2015.<br><br>Instructors: Dr. J\ufffd\ufffdrgen Groeneveld (Helmholtz Centre for Environmental<br>Research \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd UFZ, Germany) and Dr. Alexander Singer (Helmholtz Centre for<br>Environmental Research \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd UFZ, Germany).<br><br>Site: Els Hostalets de Pierola, Barcelona, Spain.<br><br>Agent-Based Models (ABM), or Individual Based Models, are one of a class of<br>computational models for simulating the actions and interactions of<br>autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as<br>organizations or groups) with a view to assessing their effects on the<br>system as a whole. In this [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T09:21:39+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Soledad De Esteban Trivigno</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a5c3d7a6.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a27f4d86.1502">   <title>EAA Conference Session Advertisement </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a27f4d86.1502</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br>Abstracts are invited for the session 'Scientific techniques to examine human interaction with woodlands' at the European Association of Archaeologists conference, Glasgow, September 2-5 2015. The deadline for submissions is Monday the 16th of February.<br>Woodlands have been integral to everyday life for thousands of years, from providing an environment for hunting and foraging to becoming an important managed resource for timber and recreation. Yet, compared to many other disciplines such as bio-archaeology, the study of how people interacted with past woodlands has been relatively undervalued. To date scientific analyses, such as palynology have been largely applied to [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-13T12:04:29+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Scott Timpany</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;a27f4d86.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f158658.1502">   <title>EAA 2015 Call for Papers: Integrated Approaches to Spatial Analysis in Domestic and Inhabited Contexts </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f158658.1502</link>   <description> Dear Colleagues,<br><br>Apologies for cross-posting. We look forward to your submissions via the<br>online submission system: http://eaaglasgow2015.com/call-for-papers/ [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-13T10:23:11+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Hayley McParland</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;f158658.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;2ead7954.1502">   <title>EAA Glasgow 2015: Exploring new trends and lost(?) tracks in landscape archaeology Session </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;2ead7954.1502</link>   <description> -Apologies for Cross Posting-<br><br>CALL FOR PAPERS:<br><br>Dear colleagues,<br><br>Another quick reminder that the deadline for submitting abstracts for EAA Glasgow 2015 (16th of February 2015) is approaching very fast now<br>and here's an interdisciplinary session between the humanities and sciences you might like to contribute to!<br><br>Exploring new trends and lost(?) tracks in landscape archaeology<br>This session explores actual and future alternatives in archaeological landscape research. It focuses on questions which call for interdisciplinary approaches, both exploring new trends and lost tracks. Although landscape archaeology has made significant progress over the past decades, many archaeologists share the feeling that [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-13T10:13:07+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Kluiving, S.J.</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;2ead7954.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d307e5d6.1502">   <title>EAA Glasgow 2015 call for papers: 'The filthy reality of everyday life?': Reflections on dirt from prehistory to the present </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d307e5d6.1502</link>   <description> -Apologies for Cross Posting-<br><br>CALL FOR PAPERS:<br><br>Dear colleagues,<br><br>Abstracts are invited for submission to the session *'The filthy reality of<br>everyday life? Reflections on dirt from prehistory to the present' *(Session<br>ID AR1: Interpreting the Archaeological Record) at the European Association<br>of Archaeologists Conference, Glasgow, September 2-5 2015. Submission<br>deadline: Monday 16th February 2015.<br><br>Since the BBC documentary *Filthy Cities *opened with a revolting picture<br>of medieval London, the long held popular notion of medieval towns as<br>unorganized, cluttered and filthy has seriously taken root in the<br>collectively memory. The notion stems from a traditional focus on studying<br>normative [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-12T11:31:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Eileen Reilly</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;d307e5d6.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;478807ba.1502">   <title>EAA Glasgow - Don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt put your eggs in one basket (Apologies for any cross-posting)</title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;80bb89ee.1502</link>   <description> Dear All,<br><br>Just a quick reminder that the deadline for submitting abstracts for EAA Glasgow 2015 (16th of February 2015) is less than a week away!<br><br>We as such we would like to continue to invite submissions for our session on multi-disciplinary approaches to poultry exploitation in Europe.<br>We very much look forward to your submissions and hope to see many of you in Glasgow.<br>Please don’t hesitate to get in touch with any questions.<br>Best Wishes,<br>Julia Best (and the Chicken Project Team http://www.scicultchickens.org/) [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-11T10:47:12+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Julia Best</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;80bb89ee.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;7495c6b2.1502">   <title>AEA seminar: Oxford, 2nd March </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;7495c6b2.1502</link>   <description> Dear All,<br><br>Another AEA seminar for your diary:<br><br>2nd March 17.00<br><br>Professor Soultana Valamoti (Aristotle University of Thessaloniki): 'A sip of Neolithic wine: recent finds from the north Aegean'<br><br>Institute of Archaeology Lecture Room, 36 Beaumont Street, University of Oxford, Oxford, OX1 2PG<br><br>Refreshments will be served. Submission deadline: 16 February 2015. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-10T08:41:09+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ricardo Fernandes</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;6178b117.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;e1b15171.1502">   <title>Call for Papers: From Anthrosphere to Lithosphere (and back again): A Celebration of the Career and Research of Terry O'Connor (AEA annual conference 2015) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ENV-ARCH;e1b15171.1502</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>We're delighted to announce that this year's AEA annual conference will be<br>held at the University of York, in honour of Terry O'Connor, from 6th<br>November to 8th November.<br><br>Terry, who retired at the start of the year, has been an influential figure<br>in the field of zooarchaeology and environmental archaeology for more than<br>30 years, not least as a founding member of the Association of Environmental<br>Archaeology (AEA) and co-editor of its first journal, Circaea. Terry has had<br>a considerable impact on students of environmental archaeology and<br>zooarchaeology during the last two decades, as a writer of [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-04T09:45:43-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Lee G.
